{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3556700,"name":"","username":"walnut","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ea5d25/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T01:44:48.939Z","cooked":"

This is our first year of programming swerve drive, and we’ve been using the YAGSL documentation and example code. We currently have 3 big issues:

  • The offset of the modules seems to reset every time we deploy the code (whatever orientation the wheels are at when code is deployed becomes the “zero” point).
  • When driving with the left joystick, the wheels just spin in circles UNLESS the joystick is pointed at either the top right or bottom right corner of the joystick (no idea why).
  • When rotating, only two of the wheels orient themselves correctly (more or less).
  • One module turns but does not drive.
    I’ve gone through the 8 debugging steps that were recommended on the YAGSL documentation and have made sure the IDs are correct (to our knowledge at least).
    We’re using mk4i for the swerve base along with CANcoders, NEOs (SPARKMAX), and a navX2 mounted on the RoboRio. We’ve been working on the issue for about a week now and still have no clue what the issue could be.
    Here’s the link to the code:
    GitHub - Dayglowv/YAGSL-Example-2025.7.1DAYGLOW

walnut:

The offset of the modules seems to reset every time we deploy the code (whatever orientation the wheels are at when code is deployed becomes the “zero” point).

Are your CANcoder offset measurements all really that small?

They are entered in degrees, not rotations, and yours all look suspiciously close to 0 [meaning they might be in rotations in your mind, but degrees to YAGSL], which would explain why deploying them always sets them to very close to 0.

We have exactly the same hardware (probably a different robot size, different CAN IDs, and obviously different CANcoder offsets), but while we’re not going to set the world on fire tomorrow (er, later today… ) at URI, we have basically working code, so it this post isn’t the full answer to number 1, feel free to snag ours, make the offsets what you need yours to be and see if that works on your bot better than yours.

I was using the raw position I found in Phoenix Tuner. After taking another look at it, I’m pretty sure the values are in rotations, like you said. How would I go about converting them to degrees?
